qas.question: President Thomas Jefferson had a relationship with who?
What was the name of the Smithsonian-Monticello exhibit that discussed their relationship?

answers.text: Slavery at Monticello: The Paradox of Liberty

qas.question: How long were Jefferson and Hemmings in a relationship?
Which child of Jefferson identified as black?
How much of the children of Jefferson and Hemmings were white?
What slave did George Washington have a relationship with?
How long were Washington and Hemings in a relationship for?
How many of the Hemings children moved to the south?
What was it socially disadvantageous for the Hemings children to do?
Who was legally black under Virginia law at the time?

context: Of numerous relationships between male slaveholders, overseers, or master's sons and women slaves, the most notable is likely that of President Thomas Jefferson with his slave <a0_0><b5_0>Sally Hemings<b5_0/><a0_0/>. As noted in the 2012 collaborative Smithsonian-Monticello exhibit, <a1_0>Slavery at Monticello: The Paradox of Liberty<a1_0/>, Jefferson, then a widower, took Hemings as his concubine for <a2_0>nearly <b6_0>40 years<b6_0/><a2_0/>. They had six children of record; four Hemings children survived into adulthood, and he freed them all, among the very few slaves he freed. Two were allowed to "escape" to the North in 1822, and two were granted freedom by his will upon his death in 1826. <a4_0>Seven-eighths<a4_0/> white by ancestry, all <b7_0>four<b7_0/> of his Hemings children moved to northern states as adults; three of the four entered the white community, and all their descendants identified as white. Of the descendants of <a3_0>Madison Hemings<a3_0/>, who continued to identify as black, some in future generations eventually identified as white and "married out", while others continued to identify as African American. It was socially advantageous for the Hemings children to <b8_0>identify as white<b8_0/>, in keeping with their appearance and the majority proportion of their ancestry. Although born into slavery, the <b9_0>Hemings children<b9_0/> were legally white under Virginia law of the time.
